data.Title: Mental Health First Aid Training
data.Description:
Led by Jan LeBahn, LISW, former School Social Worker at Grinnell-Newburg High School, and Certified MHFA Trainer.


  Mental Health First Aid (MHFA) teaches you how to identify, understand, and respond to signs of mental health and substance use challenges among children and adults. This is an invaluable skill to learn and helps individuals’ resumes stand out regardless of intended industry.


  Participants will earn the official MHFA training certification from the National Council for Mental Wellbeing.

data.Title: Superfest mini-fest
Black Church at Grinnell
data.Description:
A spirit-filled Christian worship service in an African American tradition. Reverend Titus E. Bryant will be preaching on “Overcoming Overnight Activism”


  Reverend Titus E. Bryant is a preacher, speaker, and community organizer dedicated to faith-centered social impact. A Houston native and graduate of Prairie View A&M University and Wesley Theological Seminary, he has worked to mobilize faith communities in Texas, Washington, D.C., and Chicago to address injustice, health disparities, and criminal justice reform. He currently serves as a Policy Organizer with Live Free Illinois and an Associate Pastor at Trinity United Church of Christ while cherishing his roles as a husband and father.


  Music by the The Young, Gifted and Black Gospel Choir directed by Barry Jones.


  All are welcome! Please join us!

data.Title: Grief Drop-In Support Space
data.Description: CRSSJ and SHAW will hold a supportive space for those who are grieving the loss of a loved one such as a parent, family member, partner, friend, or peer. This weekly event in the CRSSJ Prayer Garage will provide a healing space for those who have experienced a significant loss and wish to connect with a community of grievers. Our goals are to support connection, exploration of feelings connected to loss, and reflection on grief that continues to impact day-to-day life. This programming is not a replacement for therapy or psychiatric care; referrals are available upon request. As a drop-in space, there is no ongoing commitment, and you are welcome to attend whichever dates you choose.
data.Org: Crssj, Student Affairs, Student Health & Wellness

data.Description: Did you know that one pint of blood can be separated out into its components - red blood cells, platelets, and plasma - and save three local hospital patients? data.Title: BAX Visiting Artist Talk
data.Description:
Our lives consist of internal and external landscapes. My work examines the ways in which these landscapes intersect and are altered by such intersections. Paper becomes the “border-line surface,” the membrane that divides and connects what is inside us and what is outside.


  Landscape consists not only of the physical realities of our surroundings, but of our relationship to those realities. J. Douglas Porteous calls landscape “a visual construct [that] does not exist without an observer.” In observing, we project ourselves onto and into the landscape. Individual landscapes, however, also dictate how we observe them. The landscape is inside us as much as we are inside it.


  My prints act as representations and embodiments of this interplay of outer and inner space. I represent relationships and the spaces that contain and create them abstractly, in hopes that viewers will use the space of the landscape as a site for meditation on the relationships and spaces in their own lives. Often, ink transfers from the block to the paper, but the residue of previous impressions also transfers from the paper back to the block and then onto subsequent prints. Through this exchange, the surface documents a conversation, the way we are changed by contact with new environments and ideas. In installation or book form, this surface expands to form its own environment.


  My recent work engages the reciprocal relationship between inner and outer space, between people and our environments, in the landscapes of the Western and Midwestern United States.  ceding clouds, Controlled Burn and Fire Maps explore this relationship through the lens of ?re — the imprints left by wild?re, on the part of the landscape, and prescribed burns, on the part of people. Emigrant Lake[s] addresses drought’s effects on the Western landscape and its population. Lagoons and Fringe Landscapes emerge from the beauties and horrors of modern agriculture. Lagoons references the lurid colors of the waste containment tanks used by industrial hog farms. Fringe Landscapes arises from the notion of a corn field as a grassland that contains our longing for the now-gone prairie grasslands. defensible space and a belly full of water against the future drought use cactus imagery to interrogate issues surrounding borders and scarcity.


  Across these bodies of work, the tent form is emblematic of the tenuous nature of our relationship to our surroundings, an object that allows us to connect with the landscape, to spend time in it, by separating and protecting us from it.

data.Title: Faculty/Staff Research Series
data.Description:
On a special Faculty/Staff Research Series Wednesday, April 16 event in Burling Lounge, Mariko Schimmel and Jin Feng, Department of Chinese and Japanese, will present findings about Grinnell College’s international students from China and Japan from the late 19th to the 20th century. We examine these early alumni’s experiences to explore issues of race, class, memory, and educational and cultural exchange. Refreshments will be provided


  Mariko Shigeta Schimmel is an Associate Professor of Japanese in the Department of Chinese and Japanese. She is the author of Taruho/Miraiha [Taruho/Futurist] (Kawade shobo, 1997) as well as articles on contemporary and Japanese literature in both English and Japanese. Her research interest includes proletarian and modernist literature in the 1920s and the 1930s and literature dealing with the memory of student protest in the 1960s.


  Jin Feng has been teaching Chinese language and culture for over twenty years. She has published five English monographs: The New Woman in Early Twentieth-Century Chinese Fiction (2004), The Making of a Family Saga: Ginling College 1915-1952 (2009), Romancing the Internet: Consuming and Producing Chinese Web Romance (2013), Tasting Paradise on Earth: Jiangnan Foodways (2019), and The Transpacific Flow: Creative Writing Programs in China (2024); three Chinese books such as A Book for Foodies (2020); and numerous articles in both English and Chinese. She is currently working on “Grinnell-in-China, China in Grinnell.”

data.Title: Scholars’ Convocation: Barrett Klein
data.Description: Our relationship with insects is ancient, deep, and conflicted. Insects have affected the outcomes of wars, fed civilizations, plagued populations through disease and agricultural losses, and inspired artists and engineers. Insects affect how we dress, what we eat, where we travel, and how we perceive the world. Despite the profound influence insects have had on humans’ lives, insects are often dismissed as trivial or as objects of revulsion. We are largely blind to the tiny, unintentional drivers of our culture. Understanding insects’ influence on human societies is one avenue to better understanding what it means to be human, as well as a means of appreciating the value of life’s diversity.

data.Title: Forest Bathing
data.Location: Off Campus - See EVENT DESCRIPTION for Location
data.Description: Forest bathing is the practice of taking in the natural environment though all of one’s senses. Each Thursday at 4:30pm SHAW will be leading students on a forest bathing experience. Sign-ups are required at https://forms.office.com/r/K92EGG2LD3.  Effects of forest bathing on health promotion and disease prevention in the journal Environmental Health and Preventive Medicine indicates that it increases cells that prevent cancer, reduces blood pressure, reduces stress hormones, balances the autonomic nervous system, improves sleep, and helps with insulin sensitivity. It reduces stress, anxiety, depression, anger, fatigue, and confusion. It increases the sense of vigor, thus preventing the effects of depression. There is even evidence that it may prevent the effects of COVID-19 by boosting immune function and reducing mental stress.

data.Title: Fiction Writer: Rachel Khong
data.Description: Rachel Khong is a writer living in Los Angeles. Her debut novel, Goodbye, Vitamin, won the 2017 California Book Award for First Fiction, was a Los Angeles Times Book Prize Finalist for First Fiction, and was named a Best Book of the Year by NPR; O, The Oprah Magazine; Vogue; and Esquire. Her work has appeared in The New York Times Book Review, The Cut, The Guardian, The Paris Review, and Tin House. From 2011 to 2016, she was the managing editor then executive editor of Lucky Peach magazine. With Lucky Peach, she also edited a cookbook about eggs, called All About Eggs. In 2018, she founded The Ruby, a work and event space for women and nonbinary writers and artists in San Francisco’s Mission District. Her second novel, Real Americans, was published by Knopf in April 2024, and was an instant New York Times bestseller.

data.Title: Aikido
data.Description: Aikido Practice: Aikido is a Japanese martial art dedicated to resolving conflict as peacefully as possible. It uses unified body motion, rather than upper body strength, to throw, lock, or pin attackers. We are affiliated with the United States Aikido Federation, and rank earned at Grinnell is transferrable to other dojos in our organization. Beginners are welcome to start at any time (just wear comfortable clothes).

data.Title: Holi
data.Description:
Holi, often called the “Festival of Colors,” is a vibrant and joyous celebration that marks the arrival of spring and the triumph of good over evil. Rooted in Indian culture, this festival is an exciting opportunity for students to come together and experience a unique blend of traditions, fun, and cultural appreciation.


  Celebrate diversity, embrace joy, and let the colors of Holi bring us closer together.

data.Title: Poetry Reading
data.Location: Bucksbaum 131 - Grinnell College Museum of Art
data.Description: Lívia Stein Freitas is a fourth-year English and Computer Science student whose poems have been awarded the Selden Whitcomb Award - Second Prize, as well as published in the Grinnell Review and Grinnell Underground Magazine. Through the English department’s Harris Grant, she spent a week in Boston visiting art museums to create a poetry collection (Any Ocean Can House Sirens) that is inspired by the visual arts and will be published by Grinnell Press. In this poetry reading, she will talk about the relationship between the museums’ artworks and her poems. Co-sponsored by English department, the English SEPC, Grinnell Press, and GCMoA

data.Title: Grief Drop-In Support Space
data.Description: CRSSJ and SHAW will hold a supportive space for those who are grieving the loss of a loved one such as a parent, family member, partner, friend, or peer. This weekly event in the CRSSJ Prayer Garage will provide a healing space for those who have experienced a significant loss and wish to connect with a community of grievers. Our goals are to support connection, exploration of feelings connected to loss, and reflection on grief that continues to impact day-to-day life. This programming is not a replacement for therapy or psychiatric care; referrals are available upon request. As a drop-in space, there is no ongoing commitment, and you are welcome to attend whichever dates you choose.

data.Title: Faculty/Staff Research Series
data.Description:
Please join the Grinnell College Libraries for a Research in Progress talk with Professor Lesley Delmenico (Department of Theatre, Dance, and Performance Studies). Made in collaboration with Columbia College and DePaul professors and a Northwestern PhD student, this documentary film about place is a Piscator/ Brecht/Deavere Smith-influenced montage of interviews of Evanston locals with divergent viewpoints. Interpreted by actors, seven diverse residents address issues of identity, belonging, and home in a progressive city: but one in which conversations often do not cross demographic boundaries. Issues include homelessness, racial equity and reparations, diversity and inclusivity, community policing, climate change, and immigration/displacement/remaking the self in this place.  Using techniques of ethnographic (or verbatim) theatre, engaging constructions of film and theatrical “reality,” the documentary’s activism springs from the Brechtian question, “Why does it have to be this way?”  It reflects on inequality, resourcefulness, and commitment as substrates for stories of individual loss, striving, and belonging—or not–in a city.  This workshop version of the film encourages audiences’ active viewing and speaking up, engaging in philosopher Linda Alcoff’s “speaking with” rather than the positionality of “speaking for” or “as” in discussion.  It encourages attendees to connect with stories of belonging/ unbelonging in their own locations.


  Lesley Delmenico is an associate professor of Theatre and Performance Studies (M.A., Ph.D. Northwestern University).  Her work on theatre and politics explores intersections of performance, post-coloniality, gender, and immigration, concentrating on the ways that marginalized women improvise speaking spaces in urban settings.  An ethnographic/verbatim playwright and director, she has created professional and community-based performances in London, Grinnell, Evanston IL, and Mumbai. No Bad Women, adapted from a landmark British trial, was a sold-out London production in 2019.  Her article, “Performing Public Presence: African Migrant Women Create Uncomfortable Conversations in London,” was featured by Cambridge University Press for International Women’s Day, 2020.  Recent adaptations/directions for performance and film include More than Skin Deep, an inter-racial conversation with Prof. Jan Gross (Grinnell College) and Prof. Heather Lobban-Viravong (Ursinus College). In conjunction with former Grinnell professor Lisa Avalos, Lesley has just begun work on a UK play about credibility in “false” rape accusations.

data.Title: Know Your Rights Campus Forum

data.Title: Gallery Talk
data.Location: Bucksbaum 131 - Grinnell College Museum of Art
data.Description: Enrique Chagoya has lived on both sides of the U.S.-Mexico border in the late 70’s, and in Europe in the late 90’s. His work juxtaposes secular, popular, and religious symbols to address the ongoing cultural clash between the United States, Latin America and the world as well. He uses familiar pop icons to create deceptively friendly points of entry for the discussion of complex issues. Through these seemingly harmless characters Chagoya examines the recurring subject of colonialism and oppression that continues to riddle contemporary American foreign policy. His work is found in museum collections internationally including the Museum of Modern Art, the Metropolitan Museum, the Whitney Museum, and Grinnell College Museum of Art. Co-sponsored by the Center for Humanities.
data.Org: Grinnell College Art Museum, Center For The Humanities

data.Title: Yom HaShoah
data.Description:
Holocaust survivor Andre Holten is the only survivor of his immediate family, staying alive by stowing away with a righteous family for the last two years of World War II. Andre’s experience is as a “hidden child,” after his birth parents made the excruciating, but ultimately life-saving decision to ask a Christian family to take him in.


  Andre was a Jewish 5-year-old, when he went “underground” with Johannes and Petronella Meijer in the town of Haarlem, not far from where he was born in Holland, where he hid out under a false name for the last two years of World War II. In January 1944, his parents and maternal grandparents were loaded onto a train with nearly 1,000 others, 122 of whom were children, bound for the Auschwitz concentration camp. His mother and grandparents were immediately sent to the gas chamber, while his father was forced to work in a nearby camp for around four months before he fell ill due to work conditions and was executed in August.


  Holten survived the war, completing high school under the wing of the Meijers, who he emotionally said “elected to keep” him, before immigrating to the United States in 1956, where he earned a physics degree from the City College of New York. He enlisted in the U.S. Air Force, reaching the rank of captain and helping design protection for the fuel system of the attack aircraft A-10 “Warthog” Thunderbolt II, before moving to Albuquerque and eventually becoming a substitute teacher in Rio Rancho for around 22 years. Above all, Andre feels his story is one that teaches young students to practice tolerance, and about the many different sides of humanity.

data.Title: Forest Bathing
data.Location: Off Campus - See EVENT DESCRIPTION for Location
data.Description: Forest bathing is the practice of taking in the natural environment though all of one’s senses. Each Thursday at 4:30pm SHAW will be leading students on a forest bathing experience. Sign-ups are required at https://forms.office.com/r/K92EGG2LD3.  Effects of forest bathing on health promotion and disease prevention in the journal Environmental Health and Preventive Medicine indicates that it increases cells that prevent cancer, reduces blood pressure, reduces stress hormones, balances the autonomic nervous system, improves sleep, and helps with insulin sensitivity. It reduces stress, anxiety, depression, anger, fatigue, and confusion. It increases the sense of vigor, thus preventing the effects of depression. There is even evidence that it may prevent the effects of COVID-19 by boosting immune function and reducing mental stress.

data.Title: Aikido
data.Description: Aikido Practice: Aikido is a Japanese martial art dedicated to resolving conflict as peacefully as possible. It uses unified body motion, rather than upper body strength, to throw, lock, or pin attackers. We are affiliated with the United States Aikido Federation, and rank earned at Grinnell is transferrable to other dojos in our organization. Beginners are welcome to start at any time (just wear comfortable clothes).

data.Title: Grief Drop-In Support Space
data.Description: CRSSJ and SHAW will hold a supportive space for those who are grieving the loss of a loved one such as a parent, family member, partner, friend, or peer. This weekly event in the CRSSJ Prayer Garage will provide a healing space for those who have experienced a significant loss and wish to connect with a community of grievers. Our goals are to support connection, exploration of feelings connected to loss, and reflection on grief that continues to impact day-to-day life. This programming is not a replacement for therapy or psychiatric care; referrals are available upon request. As a drop-in space, there is no ongoing commitment, and you are welcome to attend whichever dates you choose.

data.Title: Know Your Rights Campus Forum
data.Description:
As President Anne Harris shared in her welcome back message following spring break, opportunities are available in the coming months to engage in community dialog regarding ongoing changes in higher education and civil rights at the federal and state levels.


  Forums will be held from noon to 12:45 p.m., to discuss legal protections and recourse for issues. Join in person or online. Each forum will feature shared content expertise and time for questions (submit advance questions via the Campus Forums page, which includes additional resources info).

data.Title: Conversation with Dr. Tony Reid ’78
data.Location: HSSC N1164 - Global Media Event Space
data.Description:
Dr. Tony Reid, a Grinnell College alumnus (Class of 1978), is a renowned medical oncologist, professor emeritus, and CEO of Epicent/Rx. At Grinnell, he majored in political science and philosophy, which laid the foundation for his interdisciplinary approach to problem-solving.


  He earned his MD and PhD from Stanford University and has spent over two decades at UC San Diego, pioneering cancer research in gastrointestinal oncology and oncolytic viral therapy.


  Known for his commitment to patients and scientific innovation, Dr. Reid continues to inspire future generations through his leadership at EpicentRx and his dedication to advancing cancer therapies. Guests attending this event will have the unique opportunity to hear from a visionary who exemplifies the intersection of science, compassion, and creativity.
data.Org: Development And Alumni Relations, Biology Department, Center For Careers Life And Service, Sepc Biology

data.Title: Rosenfield Program Event with Lyz Lenz
data.Description:
Lyz is a New York Times bestselling author, whose writing has appeared in The Washington Post, the Columbia Journalism Review, The New York Times, and others. Her book God Land was published in 2019, through Indiana University Press. Her second book Belabored, was published in 2020 by Bold Type Books. Lyz’s essay “All the Angry Women” was also included in the anthology Not that Bad edited by Roxane Gay. Her third book, This American Ex-Wife, published in 2024, was an instant New York Times best seller. She is also the host of the This American Ex-Wife podcast.


  Lyz received her MFA in creative writing from Lesley University. She lives in Iowa with her two kids and two dogs. She writes a regular newsletter, Men Yell At Me, where she explores the intersection of politics and our bodies in red-state America.

data.Title: Alumni Symposium
data.Description:
Join us for an exclusive event where successful alumni return to share their journeys and insights into the world of finance! This is a unique opportunity to hear firsthand about the variety of career paths in finance, how to break into the industry, and the skills that will help you thrive in the field.


  The panel consists of distinguished alumni, with experience in the finance world, that will discuss the latest trends, challenges, and opportunities they have (and you will) come across. They will also provide valuable tips on job hunting, networking, and navigating your early career in finance. 


  Come and meet Paige Carlson ’05, Vice President, Financial Planner and Wealth Advisor at Grinnell State Bank; Cindy Harris ’94, Chief Financial Office of Iowa Finance Authority; Steve Pickle ’90, Chief People Officer at Samsara; Ahsan Rahim ’11, Global Head of Pricing for Payments and connect at Stripe; Shekhar Shah ’01, Managing Director at Citi, and Yuki Narula, CFO of Exit 182 Group, LLC.


  This event is the perfect chance to gain advice, ask questions, and build connections that could shape your professional future. Don’t miss this opportunity to learn from those who’ve been in your shoes and are now thriving in their careers! Open to all majors and all class years.

data.Title: Circle Gathering
data.Description:
Are you walking a Pagan Path?


  Are you drawn to nature-centered spiritual practices?


  Are you curious to learn more?


  Come to Circle Gathering!


  Circle is a space for those who are interested in exploring pagan or nature-centered spiritual paths. We will spend our time together discussing texts and beliefs, sharing practices, walking in nature, meditating, drumming, and more.


   Our Gatherings will take place on Thursdays at 4:00 pm in the CRSSJ Prayer Garage


  Circle Gathering is led by Carolyn Herbst Lewis. For more information or for spiritual discussion, email Carolyn at [lewiscar].

data.Title: Forest Bathing
data.Location: Off Campus - See EVENT DESCRIPTION for Location
data.Description: Forest bathing is the practice of taking in the natural environment though all of one’s senses. Each Thursday at 4:30pm SHAW will be leading students on a forest bathing experience. Sign-ups are required at https://forms.office.com/r/K92EGG2LD3.  Effects of forest bathing on health promotion and disease prevention in the journal Environmental Health and Preventive Medicine indicates that it increases cells that prevent cancer, reduces blood pressure, reduces stress hormones, balances the autonomic nervous system, improves sleep, and helps with insulin sensitivity. It reduces stress, anxiety, depression, anger, fatigue, and confusion. It increases the sense of vigor, thus preventing the effects of depression. There is even evidence that it may prevent the effects of COVID-19 by boosting immune function and reducing mental stress.

data.Title: Grief Drop-In Support Space
data.Description: CRSSJ and SHAW will hold a supportive space for those who are grieving the loss of a loved one such as a parent, family member, partner, friend, or peer. This weekly event in the CRSSJ Prayer Garage will provide a healing space for those who have experienced a significant loss and wish to connect with a community of grievers. Our goals are to support connection, exploration of feelings connected to loss, and reflection on grief that continues to impact day-to-day life. This programming is not a replacement for therapy or psychiatric care; referrals are available upon request. As a drop-in space, there is no ongoing commitment, and you are welcome to attend whichever dates you choose.

data.Title: Circle Gathering
data.Description:
Are you walking a Pagan Path?


  Are you drawn to nature-centered spiritual practices?


  Are you curious to learn more?


  Come to Circle Gathering!


  Circle is a space for those who are interested in exploring pagan or nature-centered spiritual paths. We will spend our time together discussing texts and beliefs, sharing practices, walking in nature, meditating, drumming, and more.


   Our Gatherings will take place on Thursdays at 4:00 pm in the CRSSJ Prayer Garage


  Circle Gathering is led by Carolyn Herbst Lewis. For more information or for spiritual discussion, email Carolyn at [lewiscar].

data.Title: Forest Bathing
data.Location: Off Campus - See EVENT DESCRIPTION for Location
data.Description: Forest bathing is the practice of taking in the natural environment though all of one’s senses. Each Thursday at 4:30pm SHAW will be leading students on a forest bathing experience. Sign-ups are required at https://forms.office.com/r/K92EGG2LD3.  Effects of forest bathing on health promotion and disease prevention in the journal Environmental Health and Preventive Medicine indicates that it increases cells that prevent cancer, reduces blood pressure, reduces stress hormones, balances the autonomic nervous system, improves sleep, and helps with insulin sensitivity. It reduces stress, anxiety, depression, anger, fatigue, and confusion. It increases the sense of vigor, thus preventing the effects of depression. There is even evidence that it may prevent the effects of COVID-19 by boosting immune function and reducing mental stress.

data.Title: Grief Drop-In Support Space
data.Description: CRSSJ and SHAW will hold a supportive space for those who are grieving the loss of a loved one such as a parent, family member, partner, friend, or peer. This weekly event in the CRSSJ Prayer Garage will provide a healing space for those who have experienced a significant loss and wish to connect with a community of grievers. Our goals are to support connection, exploration of feelings connected to loss, and reflection on grief that continues to impact day-to-day life. This programming is not a replacement for therapy or psychiatric care; referrals are available upon request. As a drop-in space, there is no ongoing commitment, and you are welcome to attend whichever dates you choose.

data.Title: Aikido
data.Description: Aikido Practice: Aikido is a Japanese martial art dedicated to resolving conflict as peacefully as possible. It uses unified body motion, rather than upper body strength, to throw, lock, or pin attackers. We are affiliated with the United States Aikido Federation, and rank earned at Grinnell is transferrable to other dojos in our organization. Beginners are welcome to start at any time (just wear comfortable clothes).

data.Title: The Future of Shared-Use Kitchens
data.Description: Join us for an engaging panel discussion, The Future of Shared-Use Kitchens. This event will explore the exciting opportunity of a shared-use kitchen coming to Poweshiek County and how it can support the growth of local food businesses. Hear from a dynamic group of panelists—including food entrepreneurs, economic development leaders, and university specialists—about the potential to empower food entrepreneurs, scale home production, and foster community collaboration.

data.Title: Circle Gathering
data.Description:
Are you walking a Pagan Path?


  Are you drawn to nature-centered spiritual practices?


  Are you curious to learn more?


  Come to Circle Gathering!


  Circle is a space for those who are interested in exploring pagan or nature-centered spiritual paths. We will spend our time together discussing texts and beliefs, sharing practices, walking in nature, meditating, drumming, and more.


   Our Gatherings will take place on Thursdays at 4:00 pm in the CRSSJ Prayer Garage


  Circle Gathering is led by Carolyn Herbst Lewis. For more information or for spiritual discussion, email Carolyn at [lewiscar].

data.Title: Observatory Open House
data.Description: Join Bob Cadmus, Professor Emeritus of Physics, for a night of stargazing and discovery at our Observatory Open House! Whether you’re an astronomy enthusiast or just curious about the cosmos, this event is a great opportunity to explore the wonders of the night sky. This event is free and open to students, faculty, and the community. No RSVP required—just come ready to be amazed!

data.Title: Jazz Brunch
data.Description:
Celebrate this special day with us in the JRC dining hall, following Baccalaureate where you’ll enjoy delicious food prepared by our dining department. Indulge in a wide variety of culinary delights and specialty items!


  Tickets are highly recommended! Order in advance to secure your spot, or purchase them outside the dining hall on the day of the event.


  Don’t miss the chance to meet President Anne Harris, who will be there to welcome you and your family to an unforgettable brunch experience. We can’t wait to celebrate together!

data.Title: Grief Drop-In Support Space
data.Description: CRSSJ and SHAW will hold a supportive space for those who are grieving the loss of a loved one such as a parent, family member, partner, friend, or peer. This weekly event in the CRSSJ Prayer Garage will provide a healing space for those who have experienced a significant loss and wish to connect with a community of grievers. Our goals are to support connection, exploration of feelings connected to loss, and reflection on grief that continues to impact day-to-day life. This programming is not a replacement for therapy or psychiatric care; referrals are available upon request. As a drop-in space, there is no ongoing commitment, and you are welcome to attend whichever dates you choose.

data.Title: Celebration of Andrew Hsieh
data.Location: HSSC N1164 - Global Media Event Space
data.Description:
Emeritus of History Andrew Hsieh passed away on December 4, 2024 in Hercules, California. Andrew, who joined the Grinnell faculty in 1978, was a much beloved and respected member of the faculty for 35 years and became a professor emeritus in 2013.


  As a teacher, scholar, advisor, and mentor, Andrew helped numerous students explore their interests, pursue their goals, and travel the world. A pioneer in East Asian Studies at Grinnell College he helped generations of Grinnellians discover China.


  He is especially remembered for his pivotal role in founding, cultivating, and promoting the College’s robust program and partnership with Nanjing University in China. At a time when very few American colleges and universities had any institutional connections in China, Andrew created a multifaceted relationship that allowed Grinnell faculty to teach courses at Nanjing University, Grinnell graduates to teach English to Chinese high school students, Chinese language instructors to teach Chinese in Grinnell’s nascent East Asian language program, and Chinese scholars to reside and conduct research in Grinnell and meet with colleagues.  As a result, countless students and faculty encountered Chinese history and culture for the first time, and Andrew was a tireless and charismatic proponent of the value of such exchange. He taught Chinese and Japanese history classes at the College, while also holding concurrent professorships at Nanjing University and Anhui University in the People’s Republic of China.


  Andrew modeled the value of global education in his own pursuit of higher education, by studying abroad and in the United States. He earned a bachelor’s degree in Chinese Language and Literature at the Chinese University of Hong Kong, studied Asian History at Kyoto University (Japan), and received his Ph.D. in Asian History from Yale University. He taught at Case Western Reserve University and Skidmore College prior to coming to Grinnell. His research interests focused on the social and intellectual history of late imperial China.


  In 2019, Lu “Maggie” Bian ’09 helped establish the Professor Andrew Hsieh Career Exploration Fund in the Center for Careers, Life, and Service, both to honor her experience as one of Andrew’s students and to assist future students in their own career explorations. At the time she noted that he had taught her East Asian history, “but beyond that he was a good advisor and mentor. I consulted with him when I was looking into study abroad programs. He helped with a letter of recommendation to graduate school. He made great contributions to the College overall. Naming the fund after him was on behalf of all the students he helped along the way.”


  Andrew had a huge impact on so many students, faculty, administrators, and staff over his long tenure at the College, and his faculty colleagues think it is important that we recognize his legacy in a way that will speak to his contributions. As we learn more about any memorial plans or tributes, we will share that information.


  Andrew, along with his wife Ming, helped to make Grinnell a more global and vibrant place; they also opened their home to colleagues and our many Nanjing visitors on countless occasions and were well known and are remembered for their wonderful hospitality and legendary dinners.


  Andrew made an enduring difference in many lives and will remain a cherished member of our community through his legacy of teaching and friendship.

data.Title: Celebration of Professor Don Smith
data.Description:
D. A. ‘Don’ Smith, 88, Professor Emeritus of History, died August 10, 2024, at the University of Iowa Hospitals, having recently suffered a stroke. A British historian who was a beloved mentor and teacher, he leaves a half-century legacy of service to Grinnell College, having joined the faculty in 1970, moving from his post as assistant professor at Yale University. A native of Cleveland, Tennessee, he earned a bachelor’s degree at Vanderbilt University, bachelor’s and master’s degrees at Oxford University, where he was Rhodes Scholar (with specializations in both British and French history), and a doctorate at Yale University.


  As a faculty member in Grinnell College’s Department of History, Don offered courses in British history, and he partnered with faculty colleagues across the curriculum to team teach interdisciplinary courses, such as a celebrated course on The Enlightenment, in the 1970s and 1980s. In 2000 he was named L. F. Parker Professor of History. He considered his tutorial and his seminar on Alexis de Tocqueville, designed and taught as a senior faculty member, among the highlights of his teaching career.


  Don’s service to the academic mission of the college was extraordinary. He was chair of the faculty from 1986-1988. His service also included multiple terms as chair of the Department of History and as a member of the Executive Council. He was on the initial faculty planning group that, under the leadership of President George Drake and Professor Andrew Hsieh, established the College’s institutional partnership with Nanjing University in China – one of the first U.S. colleges to do so. Over more than two decades, “Lao Shi Smith” taught courses and delivered lectures at Nanjing University, where he was revered by his Chinese colleagues.


  From 1970-2001 Don was the college’s adviser for Rhodes and Marshall Scholarships. In addition to his service to the Grinnell College’s Phi Beta Kappa chapter, he served in different leadership roles – including president of Beta of Iowa. A long-time member of the Public Events Committee at the college, he – collaborating with Georgia Dentel, the college’s liaison to performing arts professionals – brought prominent classical musicians to the community. His interest in opera infused the arts programming that he championed. He was also an advocate of the architecture on the Grinnell College campus, with a keen appreciation of The Forum, even interviewing famed architect Walter Netsch who designed The Forum, as part of a recognition of the building and its legacy.


  Don was a life-long Democrat, and his involvement in and leadership of the Poweshiek County Democratic Party extended over his decades in Grinnell. Through his work in party politics, he established friendships with Iowans from all walks of life, taking great pride in his connections to people in the small communities of Poweshiek County and his ability to traverse the back-roads of the state like an Iowa native. He was devoted to the Iowa Democratic caucuses. In the 1992 presidential election, he was a member of the Electoral College, casting his electoral vote for the Clinton/Gore ticket.


  Don was preceded in death by his mother and father, Frances (née Higgins) and Tip Smith, as well as his brother, Gary K. Smith. He is survived by his family in Cleveland, Tennessee – sister-in-law Marguerite Smith; nieces and nephews Kent (Karen) Smith, Alan (Kelly) Smith, Leslie (Barrett) Painter and Lindsey (Thomas) Bell, along with many great nieces and nephews who adored him. His network of colleagues, former students and friends extends across the world.


  Drop in any time, with remarks by family and friends at 3 p.m.

data.Title: Faculty/Staff Research Series
data.Description:
On a special Faculty/Staff Research Series Wednesday, April 16 event in Burling Lounge, Mariko Schimmel and Jin Feng, Department of Chinese and Japanese, will present findings about Grinnell College’s international students from China and Japan from the late 19th to the 20th century. We examine these early alumni’s experiences to explore issues of race, class, memory, and educational and cultural exchange. Refreshments will be provided


  Mariko Shigeta Schimmel is an Associate Professor of Japanese in the Department of Chinese and Japanese. She is the author of Taruho/Miraiha [Taruho/Futurist] (Kawade shobo, 1997) as well as articles on contemporary and Japanese literature in both English and Japanese. Her research interest includes proletarian and modernist literature in the 1920s and the 1930s and literature dealing with the memory of student protest in the 1960s.


  Jin Feng has been teaching Chinese language and culture for over twenty years. She has published five English monographs: The New Woman in Early Twentieth-Century Chinese Fiction (2004), The Making of a Family Saga: Ginling College 1915-1952 (2009), Romancing the Internet: Consuming and Producing Chinese Web Romance (2013), Tasting Paradise on Earth: Jiangnan Foodways (2019), and The Transpacific Flow: Creative Writing Programs in China (2024); three Chinese books such as A Book for Foodies (2020); and numerous articles in both English and Chinese. She is currently working on “Grinnell-in-China, China in Grinnell.”
data.Org: Library, Chinese Japanese Department, History Department

data.Title: Community Friday
data.Description: At the next Community Friday on April 18th, the CTLA is pleased to welcome Phil Jones, Associate Professor, Humanities Librarian and Coordinator of Research Services, and Libby Cave,  Assistant Professor, Digital Humanities and Instruction Librarian. Join us to learn about and to help shape library programming that provides support and community for students and faculty conducting research during the summer. At this event, Phil and Libby will share their planned topics and schedule for summer 2025. They also welcome your suggestions and insights so their summer programming best supports all scholars on campus this summer. The CTLA thanks Grinnell College Libraries for their generous support of this event.

data.Title: Faculty/Staff Research Series
data.Description:
Please join the Grinnell College Libraries for a Research in Progress talk with Professor Lesley Delmenico (Department of Theatre, Dance, and Performance Studies). Made in collaboration with Columbia College and DePaul professors and a Northwestern PhD student, this documentary film about place is a Piscator/ Brecht/Deavere Smith-influenced montage of interviews of Evanston locals with divergent viewpoints. Interpreted by actors, seven diverse residents address issues of identity, belonging, and home in a progressive city: but one in which conversations often do not cross demographic boundaries. Issues include homelessness, racial equity and reparations, diversity and inclusivity, community policing, climate change, and immigration/displacement/remaking the self in this place.  Using techniques of ethnographic (or verbatim) theatre, engaging constructions of film and theatrical “reality,” the documentary’s activism springs from the Brechtian question, “Why does it have to be this way?”  It reflects on inequality, resourcefulness, and commitment as substrates for stories of individual loss, striving, and belonging—or not–in a city.  This workshop version of the film encourages audiences’ active viewing and speaking up, engaging in philosopher Linda Alcoff’s “speaking with” rather than the positionality of “speaking for” or “as” in discussion.  It encourages attendees to connect with stories of belonging/ unbelonging in their own locations.


  Lesley Delmenico is an associate professor of Theatre and Performance Studies (M.A., Ph.D. Northwestern University).  Her work on theatre and politics explores intersections of performance, post-coloniality, gender, and immigration, concentrating on the ways that marginalized women improvise speaking spaces in urban settings.  An ethnographic/verbatim playwright and director, she has created professional and community-based performances in London, Grinnell, Evanston IL, and Mumbai. No Bad Women, adapted from a landmark British trial, was a sold-out London production in 2019.  Her article, “Performing Public Presence: African Migrant Women Create Uncomfortable Conversations in London,” was featured by Cambridge University Press for International Women’s Day, 2020.  Recent adaptations/directions for performance and film include More than Skin Deep, an inter-racial conversation with Prof. Jan Gross (Grinnell College) and Prof. Heather Lobban-Viravong (Ursinus College). In conjunction with former Grinnell professor Lisa Avalos, Lesley has just begun work on a UK play about credibility in “false” rape accusations.

    Pizza: Sunny Smoked Brisket Breakfast Pizza, Cheese Pizza and Pepperoni Pizza

data.Title: Gallery Talk
data.Location: Bucksbaum 131 - Grinnell College Museum of Art
data.Description: Enrique Chagoya has lived on both sides of the U.S.-Mexico border in the late 70’s, and in Europe in the late 90’s. His work juxtaposes secular, popular, and religious symbols to address the ongoing cultural clash between the United States, Latin America and the world as well. He uses familiar pop icons to create deceptively friendly points of entry for the discussion of complex issues. Through these seemingly harmless characters Chagoya examines the recurring subject of colonialism and oppression that continues to riddle contemporary American foreign policy. His work is found in museum collections internationally including the Museum of Modern Art, the Metropolitan Museum, the Whitney Museum, and Grinnell College Museum of Art. Co-sponsored by the Center for Humanities.

It uses unified body motion, rather than upper body strength, to throw, lock, or pin attackers. We are affiliated with the United States Aikido Federation, and rank earned at Grinnell is transferrable to other dojos in our organization. Beginners are welcome to start at any time (just wear comfortable clothes).
